_header: When bright Phoebus passed was the Ram
Note: All MSS are more or less imperfect, except Oxford, Bodleian Library Laud misc. 557 (SC 1124) and London, British Library Arundel 119.
_description: John Lydgate, The Siege of Thebes — 4716 lines in couplets

Bod776.First Lines:
Whan aurora was in þe morowe redeand Iubiter in þe
                    crabbes hed…
Bod776.Last Lines:
…Here is now ended a fynal destrucciounof mighty Thebes
                    þat strong & roial toun
Bod776.Attributed Title:
Here endeth þe Destrucc… (at the end, partly
                    unreadable)

BodDig230.First Lines:
ffully in purpos to come vnto dinereVn to Ospringe and breke
                    þere oure faste…
BodDig230.Last Lines:
…And Ioye eternal whan we hens wendeOf my tale thus I make an
                    ende
BodDig230.Attributed Title:
Here endith the Sege of Thebes And begyneth the Sege of Troye (at the
                    end)

BodLauMis416.First Lines:
Whan bright phebus passid was þe ramMid of aprell & in
                    þe bull cam…
BodLauMis416.Last Lines:
…And ioy eternall whan we hennys wendOf my tale þus I
                    make an end
BodLauMis416.Attributed Title: Here endith þe distruccion of thebes (at the end)

BodRawC48.First Lines:
Whan phebus passid was the RamMid of aprill & in the bole
                    cam…
BodRawC48.Last Lines:
…And thus eendith the fynal destrucciounOff worthi Thebes the
                    myhti Roiall toun
BodRawC48.Attributed Title: Explicit finalis destructio Cuntatis Thebanorum (at the end)

OxfChrCh152.First Lines:
Whan Phebus passed was the RamMidde of Aprile and into the bole
                    cam…
OxfChrCh152.Last Lines:
…Of Martes swerdes shal nomore manaceNor his spere greuous to
                    sustene

OxfStJohn266.Note:
Exemplar for 
            Lydgate, John, The Storye [of The Siege] of Thebes, [de Worde, 1497?] ; see Bone (1931)
XBone,  G. 
             “Extant Manuscripts Printed from by W. de Worde with Notes on the Owner,
                Roger Thorney.” 
             The Library
         4th ser. 12 (1931-1932): 284-306; listed as MS 256 in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943.

CamMagPep2011.First Lines:
WHan phebus passed was the RameMidde of Aprill and in to þe
                    boll came…
CamMagPep2011.Last Lines:
…And Ioy eternall whan we hense wendeAnd of my Tale thus y
                    make an Ende
CamMagPep2011.Attributed Title:
The Destruccioun of Thebes (contemporary) (f. 1); Here endeth the
                    distruccioun off Thebes secundum lidgate Monke off Bury (f.
                    76v)

BLAdd5140.First Lines:
WHan briht phebus passid was the RamMyd of Aprill and in to the
                    boole cam…
BLAdd5140.Last Lines:
All clad in blak with her wymplys whiteWith gret honour and dwe
                    reuerence…
BLAdd5140.Attributed Title:
Incipit ultima de fabulus Canuarie / translata per Dompnum / Iohannem
                        lidgate monachum / in redundo a Canuaria Incipit prologus (f.
                        259v)

BLAdd18632.Transcription:
Whanne briȝte Phebus Passed was þe RamMid of April & in
                    to þe bole camAnd Saturne olde with his ffrosti ffaceIn virgyn
                    taken haþ his placeMalincolik and slow of mocioun And was al so
                    in þe opposicioun[…]Of gret Rome so royal and
                    LargeWhane the ladies departed from Argeo her cuntrees ful trist and
                    desolatLo here the fyn of contek and debatLo here þe miȝt of
                    Mars the sterreLo what hit is to bi gune a werreHow hit concludiþ
                    ensample ye may seffirst of grekes and sith of this Citee
BLAdd18632.Note:
A 6-line fragment of the beginning of Siege of Thebes, then an
                    8-line passage, possibly also extracted from Siege of Thebes, both
                    written by the same hand as the full copy just ended in first
                    column.

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Whan brighte phebus passid was the RamMid of aprill &
                    intoþe bole cam…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…And Ioye etarnall whan we hens wendeof my tale thus I make an
                    ende
BLAdd29729.Note:
Below last line, f. 83, ‘lawes deo’ [sic] by scribe
                    (John Stow).
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
her endyth the sege of worthy thebes by Iohn lydgatt monk of bury on his
                    sowll god have mercy wretyn by Iohn Stowe (f. 83, below end of text; written in
                    rubric by scribe, John Stow)

BLCottAppXXVII.First Lines:
Whan bryght Phebus passyd was the RamMyd of Aprell and In to bole
                    kam…
BLCottAppXXVII.Last Lines:
…Off here wepynge was som whatt ouergonThe lyttyll course was
                    grayun vnder stone…
BLCottAppXXVII.Note: Lines 1-3408. Final folio is badly damaged.

BLEge2864.First Lines:
[W]Han bright Phebus passid was the RamMid of Aprill and to the
                    foule cam…
BLEge2864.Last Lines:
…And Ioye eternall whan we haue weendeAnd of my tale thus I
                    make an eende
BLEge2864.Attributed Title:
Heer begynneth the last tale of Cauntirbury / talis tolde homward and maad
                    bi dan John / Lidgate Monk of Bury (f. 292v); Heere endith the laste
                    tale of Cauntirbury / maad and told be Dan Iohn Lidgate Monachi (f.
                    341)

BLRoy18Dii.First Lines:
Whan bright Phebus passyd was þe ramMid of Aprile and in the
                    bulle cam…
BLRoy18Dii.Last Lines:
…And Ioye eternall whan we hens wendeOf my tale thus I
                    make an ende. Amen
BLRoy18Dii.Attributed Author: In this preamble shortly is comprihendid a Mery conseyte of John lydgate Monke of Bury declarynge how he aionyde þe sege of Thebes to the mery tallys of Caunterburye (f. 147ra, in rubric)
BLRoy18Dii.Attributed Title: In this preamble shortly is comprihendid a Mery conseyte of John lydgate Monke of Bury declarynge how he aionyde þe sege of Thebes to the mery tallys of Caunterburye (f. 147ra, in rubric); Here now endeth as ye may see The destruccyon of Thebes the Cytee (f. 162va, rubric)

With rubric text-divisions or glosses written between lines of text

Now is here ended the fynal destruccyon / of myghty Thebes that strong
